channel.title: NYT > Arts
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Lively v. Baldoni Tests What Crosses the Line on a ‘Steamy’ Movie Set
item.description: An affectionate slow dance. References to pornography. What rises to harassment on the set of a movie about a sexual relationship that turns violent?
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs

item.title: Billy Idol Had It All, and Then He ‘Lit It With Butane’
item.description: Last year, the British rocker with the iconic sneer played his biggest tour yet. At 70, he’s revealing how he survived the tough times in a new documentary.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik
item.media:credit: Ariel Fisher for The New York Times

item.title: Writing an Ancient Egyptian Afterlife, in 21 Feet of Scroll
item.description: How would a New York Times obituary writer measure up to the scribes of the Book of the Dead? He found out at the Brooklyn Museum.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: Berlin Film Festival Tried to Focus on Movies. Politics Stole the Spotlight.
item.description: Reporters’ attempts to draw stars into debates about Gaza and other highly charged topics have threatened to overshadow the movies at the Berlin Film Festival.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Rogers
item.media:description: Wim Wenders, the jury president at the Berlin International Film Festival, faced a pointed political question before the first movie had even screened.

item.title: Gabriel Basso, of ‘The Night Agent,’ Gets Back to Nature
item.description: Basso stars in one of Netflix’s most popular shows. He’s still not sure how he feels about acting.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:credit: Mark Sommerfeld for The New York Times

item.title: 12 Steps and Cups of Coffee: Sobriety Has Its Moment Onstage
item.description: Plays about addiction are filling Manhattan stages this month, depicting very different places on the recovery spectrum, from harrowing to serene.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.media:description: From left, Caroline Aaron, Noah Galvin, Peter Maloney and Chip Zien in “The Reservoir” at Atlantic Theater Company in Manhattan.

item.title: Met Opera Announces 2026-27 Season: What We Want to See
item.description: Among the highlights are the world premiere of an adaptation of “Lincoln in the Bardo,” and classics like “Macbeth” and “Jenufa.”

item.title: ‘Portobello’ Review: When Italy’s Biggest TV Star Was Canceled
item.description: An HBO Max series tells the surreal true story of Enzo Tortora, brought down overnight by false accusations of being a member of the mob.
item.dc:creator: Mike Hale
item.media:description: Fabrizio Gifuni as the unjustly disgraced Italian TV star Enzo Tortora, who in the 1970s and ’80s hosted an enormously popular variety show called “Portobello.”

item.title: Tom Hiddleston and Hayley Atwell to Star in ‘Much Ado About Nothing’ on Broadway
item.description: The Marvel alumni Tom Hiddleston and Hayley Atwell will star in Jamie Lloyd’s mischievous take on “Much Ado About Nothing.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:description: Tom Hiddleston and Hayley Atwell will star as Benedick and Beatrice, the reluctant lovers at the heart of Shakespeare’s comedy classic.

item.title: ‘How to Make a Killing’ Review: Glen Powell’s Lethal Case of Entitlement
item.description: The actor stars in this comedy with a high corpse count, but the movie’s lightness soon becomes forced.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Ethan Hawke on ‘Blue Moon,’ ‘Reality Bites’ and the Lessons He’s Learned
item.description: A best actor Oscar contender for “Blue Moon,” the star reflects on turbulent times in Hollywood and the notion of selling out: “I think about it constantly.”
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan and Sela Shiloni
item.media:credit: Sela Shiloni for The New York Times
item.media:description: Acting is “such a wonderful profession,” Hawke said, explaining, “You can use your own joys and heartbreaks and relationships to educate you, then put it in service of something else.”

item.title: With a New Oscar on the Line, How Do You Judge Casting?
item.description: Contenders say the criteria for judging the category can vary from, say, the number of newcomers to the seamlessness of the ensemble.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.category: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

item.title: A Downtown Vibe Comes to Broadway This Spring
item.description: Without the usual flood of new musicals, the playwrights of works like “Becky Shaw,” “Dog Day Afternoon” and “Giant” are getting a chance to shine.
item.dc:creator: Helen Shaw

item.title: ‘Wuthering Heights’ Through the Years, from Olivier to Elordi
item.description: From Merle Oberon and Laurence Olivier to Margot Robbie and Jacob Elordi nearly a century later, the onscreen connection between Cathy and Heathcliff has taken many turns.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2, Episode 7 Recap: Emotional Rescue
item.description: Robby and Langdon have an awkward encounter in an elevator. Dana struggles to keep it together in a difficult case involving sexual assault.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:description: Langdon and Robby (Patrick Ball, left, and Noah Wyle) were finally forced to air things out ... somewhat, and under less-than-ideal circumstances.

item.title: Eric Dane, McSteamy on ‘Grey’s Anatomy,’ Dies at 53 After Battling ALS
item.description: His breakout role came in 2006 as the handsome Dr. Mark Sloan, nicknamed McSteamy, the head of plastic surgery at a Seattle hospital. He died 10 months after announcing his A.L.S. diagnosis.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: Eric Dane revealed in April 2025 that he had A.L.S.

item.title: Cees Nooteboom, Voyaging Author of Enigmatic Novels, Dies at 92
item.description: A prolific Dutch writer of fiction, poetry and travel books, he was often mentioned as a potential recipient of the Nobel Prize in Literature.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Cees Nooteboom in 2015. The author of dozens of works of fiction, poetry, journalism and travel writing, he was perennially mentioned as a possible recipient of the Nobel Prize in Literature.

item.title: Billy Steinberg, Hitmaking Lyricist of Madonna’s ‘Like a Virgin,’ Dies at 75
item.description: He co-wrote five pop-rock songs that soared to No. 1 in the 1980s and shared in a Grammy for producing Celine Dion’s 1996 album “Falling Into You.”
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: Larry Busacca/Getty Images for Songwriters Hall of Fame
item.media:description: Billy Steinberg performing at the Songwriters Hall of Fame ceremony in 2011. With fellow inductee Tom Kelly, Mr. Steinberg wrote hundreds of songs, including “True Colors,” a hit for Cyndi Lauper.

item.title: José van Dam, Suave and Riveting Opera Star, Dies at 85
item.description: One of the most esteemed singers of his era, he had a wide repertoire that included Mozart, Wagner and the title role in Messiaen’s epic “St. François d’Assise.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Kandell
item.media:description: José van Dam in 1987 as the title character in Wagner’s “The Flying Dutchman” at the San Francisco Opera.

item.title: ‘Midwinter Break’ Review: Aging Together, Growing Apart
item.description: Lesley Manville and Ciaran Hinds play an Irish married couple dealing with quiet resentments in this staid drama.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Winkelman

item.title: Van Gogh and the Meaning of Yellow
item.description: The artist gave prominence to the color during a happy period that produced some of his most famous works. But it can have many different associations, a new exhibition shows.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal
item.media:credit: Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam; Vincent van Gogh Foundation
item.media:description: Vincent van Gogh’s “Wheatfield with a Reaper” (1889)

item.title: ‘The 2026 Oscar Nominated Short Films’ Review: Major Themes, Minor Lengths
item.description: Three critics briefly consider the short films nominated for the 98th Academy Awards.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis, Alissa Wilkinson and Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘I Can Only Imagine 2’ Review: Dogged by Dark Memories
item.description: For its sequel, the Christian-themed drama about a hit single finds a new tune and an anchoring presence.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy

item.title: ‘The Dreadful’ Review: A Knight in Frightening Armor
item.description: Sophie Turner and Kit Harrington reunite after “Game of Thrones” in this deeply silly horror fable that is haunted by an ominous knight.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: Seymour Hersh, the Investigative Journalist, Is the Subject of Netflix’s “Cover-Up”
item.description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning investigative journalist who exposed a U.S. Army massacre in Vietnam is profiled in a new documentary directed by Laura Poitras and Mark Obenhaus.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television

item.title: “The Traitors” Host Alan Cumming Takes On the BAFTAs
item.description: The beloved Scottish actor and gamemaster of buzzy “The Traitors” takes center stage to host the BAFTAs.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Dulany
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: The award-winning Scottish actor Alan Cumming’s career has spanned film, theater, television and cabaret. On Sunday, Feb. 22, he will host the EE BAFTA Film Awards, known as the BAFTAs.

item.title: Fantasy Books That Imbue the Real World With Magic
item.description: The best-selling author Marie Lu recommends thrilling reads that ground enchanting adventures in recognizable settings.
item.dc:creator: Marie Lu

item.title: Stephen Colbert Sizes Up R.F.K. Jr.’s Workout With Kid Rock
item.description: “The Late Show” host called the 90-second video of the two working up a sweat together “pure cinema.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: David Hays, 95, Dies; Top Broadway Designer and Theater of Deaf Founder
item.description: He created sets and lighting for dozens of productions, including “Long Day’s Journey Into Night,” and established a new art form with his theater of the deaf, combining sign and spoken language.
item.dc:creator: Howard Fishman

item.title: Fritz Lang’s ‘Nibelungen,’ the Way It Was Meant to Be Heard
item.description: The monumental, two-film “Die Nibelungen,” drawn from similar material to Wagner’s “Ring,” is best when presented live with a full orchestra.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone

item.title: ‘Billy Preston’ Review: A Unique and Tortured Talent
item.description: The Beatles, the Stones and Clapton shared the stage with him. He made solo hits, too. A documentary by Paris Barclay explores his success and his difficult life.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny
item.category: Billy Preston: That's the Way God Planned It (Movie)

item.title: In Cynthia Erivo’s ‘Dracula,’ There’s Mirth Amid the Horror
item.description: The “Wicked” actress plays 23 roles in a one-woman show on London’s West End.
item.dc:creator: Houman Barekat
item.media:description: Real-time footage of Cynthia Erivo’s solo performance is spliced with recorded footage in the production, directed by Kip Williams.

item.title: Billy Preston’s Music Was ‘Pure Joy.’ But His Life Ended in Tragedy.
item.description: The Beatles’ beloved collaborator died at 59 in 2006. A new documentary, “That’s the Way God Planned It,” explores what he long kept hidden.
item.dc:creator: Jim Farber
item.category: Billy Preston: That's the Way God Planned It (Movie)

item.title: 5 Standout Shows During Frieze
item.description: Alongside the Frieze Los Angeles fair at the Santa Monica Airport, Feb. 26 to March 1, the city offers striking art discoveries and a celebrated group show.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Griffin

item.title: An Artist of the Unimaginable
item.description: How Michael Heizer’s massive projects have transformed the American landscape.
item.dc:creator: Hanya Yanagihara

item.title: Michael Heizer Measures His Art in Miles and Tons
item.description: It took the artist half a century of toil in the most remote parts of Nevada to build what may be the most extreme contemporary monument ever made. Now what?
item.dc:creator: M.H. Miller, Dina Litovsky and Luke Piotrowski

item.title: What to See in NYC This Spring: Broadway Shows, Concerts and More
item.description: Onstage, “Cats: The Jellicle Ball” and Adrien Brody in “The Fear of 13.” Plus: Cardi B goes on tour, Lise Davidsen takes on Isolde at the Met, 100 years of Martha Graham and more.
item.media:description: “Cats: The Jellicle Ball,” Zhailon Levingston and Bill Rauch’s radical reinvention of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s classic musical, begins previews on Broadway on March 18.

item.title: How a Visionary Collector Eyed Her Trophies
item.description: Eileen Harris Norton “built a whole new mountain and somehow got everyone to come climb up it,” the artist Mark Bradford says.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Griffin
item.media:credit: Ricardo Nagaoka for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eileen Harris Norton, an impassioned art collector, in her home in Los Angeles. She has spent decades building a collection of pieces by artists who would go on to become household names.

item.title: ‘Brokeback Mountain,’ ‘Black Swan’ and 14 More Plays and Musicals to See This Spring
item.description: Across the country, a flurry of theater productions, including “Black Swan” and “The Lunchbox,” are mining the movies for material.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.category: The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao (Play)

item.title: Stephen Colbert Finds a Place to File CBS’s Surprise Statement
item.description: “I don’t even know what to do with this,” Colbert said about the network’s news release on a scrapped interview with a Democratic politician, before putting the paper in a dog waste bag.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: Shia LaBeouf Charged With Battery in New Orleans
item.description: The actor, known for his roles in “Transformers” and “Megalopolis,” was arrested early Tuesday after reportedly assaulting two people, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: A representative for Shia LaBeouf did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Tuesday.

item.title: Readers Respond: 11 (More) Transcendent Beatles Covers by Black Musicians
item.description: Thirteen tracks were just the start. Listen to interpretations of the Fab Four via Luther Vandross, Ella Fitzgerald, Sylvester and more.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:description: Luther Vandross.

item.title: Robert Duvall Didn’t Mind Clashing With Directors
item.description: The actor had very particular thoughts on how he should — and shouldn’t — be directed, and he was happy to share them.
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy
item.media:description: Robert Duvall believed a less-is-more philosophy applied to film directing.

item.title: Kathleen Chalfant and Elizabeth Marvel Are Sobriety Sisters in ‘The Dinosaurs’
item.description: Kathleen Chalfant, Elizabeth Marvel, April Matthis and other actors deliver top-notch performances in a play that leaves questions unanswered.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:description: From left, Mallory Portnoy, Maria Elena Ramirez and Elizabeth Marvel in “The Dinosaurs” at Playwrights Horizons in Manhattan.

item.title: The Opera ‘Monster’s Paradise’ Takes Satirical Aim at Trump
item.description: “Monster’s Paradise,” by Olga Neuwirth and Elfriede Jelinek, attempts an operatic response to current events and politics. Is that possible?
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone

item.title: When Jesse Jackson Came to ‘Sesame Street’: ‘I Am! Somebody!’
item.description: His memorable appearance was brought to us by the letter ‘I,’ for inspiration.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik
item.media:description: Jesse Jackson, right, in a 1972 episode of “Sesame Street,” in which he encouraged children to assert their dignity as human beings, however small they were.

item.title: Peeking Behind the Scenes of ‘Wallace and Gromit’
item.description: An exhibition at the Young V&A in London reveals the painstaking and devoted practice of the characters’ creators, Aardman Studios.
item.dc:creator: Emily LaBarge
item.media:description: A set model from “Wallace and Gromit: Vengeance Most Fowl,” at the exhibition “Inside Aardman: Wallace and Gromit and Friends” at the Young V&A museum in London.

item.title: Robert Duvall Seared Himself Into Our Memories Even When He Wasn’t the Star
item.description: In roles as unalike as a neighborhood shut-in, a Corleone consigliere and a hardhearted military man, the actor brought an intensity that never wavered.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis
item.media:description: Robert Duvall as Tom Hagen in “The Godfather Part II.”

item.title: Romeo Is a Dead Man Would Make Kafka and Lynch Proud
item.description: Romeo Is a Dead Man features a Shakespeare-hating shape-shifter and plenty of zombies.
item.dc:creator: Harold Goldberg
item.category: Romeo Is a Dead Man (Video Game)

item.title: The 19-Year Debate over Whether a Painting Was Looted by the Nazis.
item.description: The fuzzy provenance of a Franz Marc masterwork once owned by a Jewish banker, but now held by a German museum, has fueled a lengthy dispute over its ownership.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Hickley

item.title: At 85, the Choreographer Lucinda Childs Still Has a Full Dance Card
item.description: The choreographer has a busy spring: early works at the Guggenheim’s swirling rotunda, a new appointment at Gibney Dance and a robust program at Bard.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas and Heather Sten
item.media:credit: Heather Sten for The New York Times

item.title: Daniel Radcliffe on Returning to Broadway in ‘Every Brilliant Thing’
item.description: The Tony winner returns to the stage in “Every Brilliant Thing,” an interactive monologue with a message of hope “that might be vital for somebody to hear.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson and Lucia Bell-Epstein
item.media:description: “There’s a lot about this character that I relate to, both in the way that sadness hits them, and in the way that they find joy,” Radcliffe said.

item.title: Colbert Says What CBS Told Him Not to Say
item.description: “Let’s talk about this,” Stephen Colbert said after CBS canceled a Texas state representative’s appearance on Monday’s “Late Show.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Last Week Tonight With John Oliver (TV Program)
Real Time With Bill Maher (TV Program)

item.title: Frederick Wiseman Watched People Like Nobody Else
item.description: For more than 50 years, the influential documentarian found inspiration in filming the ways his ordinary subjects lived their lives.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.media:description: Frederick Wiseman’s direct cinema style and sharp observations made him a near-peerless documentary filmmaker.

item.title: ‘Shoresy’ Is Back, a Hockey Sitcom With ‘Heated Rivalry’ Ties
item.description: If you want more Canadian TV series about emotionally complex hockey players, look no further.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray
item.media:description: Jared Keeso in a scene from Season 5 of “Shoresy.”

item.title: Robert Duvall: A Life in Pictures
item.description: The actor, who had a knack for embodying a wealth of varied characters, had a sprawling and celebrated career.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi

item.title: Frederick Wiseman, 96, Penetrating Documentarian of Institutions, Dies
item.description: He exposed abuses in films like “Titicut Follies,” a once-banned portrait of a mental hospital, but ranged widely in subject matter, from a Queens neighborhood to a French restaurant.
item.dc:creator: John Anderson
item.media:description: Mr. Wiseman in an undated photo. “I don’t know if I can offer a general definition of what I’m doing,” he said in 2011, “except to say I’m trying to create dramatic structures out of ordinary experience.”

item.title: Where to Watch Robert Duvall’s Top Performances
item.description: He played rugged, capable men drawn from America’s past, present and possible future.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray
item.media:description: In “The Godfather,” Robert Duvall played a lawyer advising a band of Italians who respect his counsel but don’t consider him a trusted insider.

item.title: Robert Duvall, ‘Godfather’ and ‘Apocalypse Now’ Actor, Dies at 95
item.description: An Oscar winner, he was known for disappearing into wide-ranging roles in movies like “Apocalypse Now” and “The Godfather” and in the television series “Lonesome Dove.”
item.dc:creator: Clyde Haberman
item.media:description: In a long and varied career, Robert Duvall was nominated for seven Academy Awards for acting, and won once.

item.title: ‘Tragedy of Coriolanus’ Swerves Off Course in Brooklyn
item.description: Theater for a New Audience’s reimagining of the Shakespearean tragedy misses an opportunity to engage the play’s many echoes with our own tense era.
item.dc:creator: Helen Shaw
item.media:description: Mickey Sumner, left, as Aufidius and McKinley Belcher III as Coriolanus in this Theater for a New Audience production at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn.

item.title: Ticket Scam Cost the Louvre $12 Million, Investigators Say
item.description: The Paris prosecutor’s office said a network involving museum employees and tour guides had been operating for a decade.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Investigators said the suspected scam at the Louvre museum in Paris involved tour guides reusing tickets for different people.
